results.name: Determinant of the circulant matrix whose rows are formed by successively rotating the vector (1, 2, 4, 8, ..., 2^(n-1)) right.
comment: Note that if the rows are rotated left instead of right, the sign of the terms for which n = 0 or 3 (mod 4) is reversed. The n eigenvalues of these circulant matrices lie on the circle of radius 2(2^n - 1)/3 centered at x = (2^n - 1)/3, y = 0. This sequence can be generalized to bases other than 2 and similar results are true.
reference: Richard Bellman, Introduction to Matrix Analysis, Second Edition, SIAM, 1970, pp. 242-3.
Philip J. Davis, Circulant Matrices, Second Edition, Chelsea, 1994.
link: Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Circulant Matrix
formula: See formulas in A180602, an unsigned version of this sequence with offset 0. [_Paul D. Hanna_, Sep 11 2010]
example: a(3) = determinant of the matrix ((1,2,4),(4,1,2),(2,4,1)) = 49. [Corrected by _T. D. Noe_, Jan 22 2008]

mathematica: Table[x=2^Range[0, n-1]; m=Table[RotateRight[x, i-1], {i, n}]; Det[m], {n, 12}]
